notes:
1. Classification of Force Systems

  • Coplanar: Lines of action of all forces lie in the same plane.
  • Concurrent: Lines of action of all forces pass through a single common point.
  • Parallel: Lines of action of all forces are parallel.
  • Collinear: Forces act along the same line.

2. Resolution of Forces

A single force can be replaced by its components. In 2D:

$$ F_x = F \cos \theta $$ $$ F_y = F \sin \theta $$

where $\theta$ is the angle measured from the x-axis.

3. Resultant of a Force System

The resultant of a system of concurrent forces is the vector sum of the individual forces. It has the same external effect on the rigid body as the original system.

$$ R_x = \sum F_x, \quad R_y = \sum F_y $$ $$ R = \sqrt{R_x^2 + R_y^2} $$ $$ \theta_R = \arctan\left(\frac{R_y}{R_x}\right) $$

For non-concurrent systems, the resultant may be a single force, a couple, or a force and a couple.

solvedExamples.question: A system of forces where all lines of action meet at a single point is called:
solvedExamples.explanation: A concurrent force system is defined by the lines of action of all forces intersecting at a common point. A particle is always subjected to a concurrent force system.

solvedExamples.question: Two concurrent forces act on a bracket: $F_1 = 200$ N at 0° and $F_2 = 300$ N at 90°. What is the magnitude of the resultant force?
solvedExamples.explanation: Since the forces are perpendicular (one along x, one along y), the magnitude is simply $R = \sqrt{F_1^2 + F_2^2} = \sqrt{200^2 + 300^2} = \sqrt{40000 + 90000} = \sqrt{130000} \approx 360.6$ N.

solvedExamples.question: A force of 100 N acts at an angle of 30° to the horizontal. What is its vertical component?
solvedExamples.explanation: The vertical component is $F_y = F \sin \theta = 100 \sin(30^\circ) = 100(0.5) = 50$ N.
